Patrick shouldn’t have had to fight the VA for care. And neither should any of our veterans. It’s time to pass H.R. 8261 and ensure that we uphold our commitment to our service members.

I’m thinking of the tragic loss of New Jersey's Patrick Duva, who died last week.

“His family said VA medical staff told Duva that his cancer was related to the toxic exposure he experienced during his military service, but VA ‘wouldn't document it.’”

https://connectingvets.radio.com/articles/29-year-old-marine-dying-of-brain-cancer-from-toxic-exposure

That’s why I’m proud to co-sponsor @RepRaulRuizMD’s bill, H.R. 8261, the Presumptive Benefits for War Fights Exposed to Burn Pits & Other Toxins Act, which would strengthen benefits for veterans suffering from burn pit related illnesses and est. presumption for overseas service.

But that still leaves an important issue unresolved: presumption. Just like with the 9/11 VCF, we need to ensure that any veteran who developed these health issues and served near burn pits is guaranteed care.

And the House has passed my amendment this summer to increase funding for research at the Airborne Hazards and Burn Pits Center of Excellence in East Orange, NJ. https://twitter.com/RepSherrill/status/1286431271481155590 QT @RepSherrill Too many veterans have been exposed to harmful chemicals from burn pits, which we know lead to greater risk of lung and respiratory diseases. Today, the House approved my amendment to increase funding for research at the Airborne Hazards and Burn Pits Center of Excellence. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1286427320950173699/img/td6Imy4UgcYHIUvr.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1286427320950173699/vid/480x270/-pxkdrwPHPihuPCb.mp4?tag=13
2️⃣ It directs DoD to provide to the VA and Congress a list of all locations where DoD used burn pits, for the purposes of research, healthcare delivery, and disability compensation.

Last year, the National Defense Authorization Act included 2 provisions to address burn pits:

1️⃣It requires any periodic health assessments for service members to include an evaluation of whether they were stationed near burn pits and/or were exposed to toxic airborne chemicals;

One of the first meetings I ever had in Congress was with @Burnpit360, Jon Stewart, and John Feal to talk about how we can do better and learn from the 9/11 VCF and their work to help those exposed to the toxic fumes from Ground Zero. I promised we would not let this go. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EmkzJR8XIAIKRo1.jpg
Burn pits have been called the Agent Orange of our generation. And that’s what it is looking like unless we stand up for our veterans and demand better.

In fact, as of September of this year, the VA denied 78 PERCENT of disability claims from burn pits: https://www.stripes.com/news/veterans/va-has-denied-about-78-of-disability-claims-from-burn-pits-1.646181

The VA has a Burn Pits Registry to document exposure and health concerns, but still maintains that research “does not show evidence of long-term health problems from exposure to burn pits.”

https://veteran.mobilehealth.va.gov/AHBurnPitRegistry/#page/home
Watch this CBS piece for an important overview of the use of burn pits and the impact on our veterans: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mOk7iAiYCOw
Too many of our veterans have been exposed to harmful chemicals from burn pits, which we know lead to increased risk of lung and respiratory diseases.

Burn pits were used in Iraq and Afghanistan to get rid of waste — and by waste, I mean everything — from batteries, to plastics, to jet fuel. And as of last year, nine were still in use across the Middle East.
🧵 This #VeteransDay, I want to renew the call for comprehensive action to address burn pits and the serious, lasting health impact their use has had on a generation of veterans.

Today, we honor our veterans by remembering all that they sacrificed to protect our lives. As a Member of Congress, @RepAOC commits above all else to recognizing the urgent needs of our veteran community: the need for respect, dignity, opportunity, and liberty.

Returning service members must have basic needs met, like housing, healthcare and mental healthcare. We must do more to facilitate smooth transitions to civilian life. And, we must stop sending our children to combat without securing these protections and safeguards first.

.@RepAOC is also committed to fighting for veterans' needs in Congress. In her first term, the House passed nearly 100 bills to support veterans, including bills to address the backlog at the VA, and provide suicide prevention support and dental care. We now must do more.

So, here’s the message to share if you know a veteran or meet one today: Never Forget.
An honor to wear the uniform and stand shoulder-to-shoulder with our friends – some of whom never made it home – to defend the freedom and way of life we are blessed with as Americans.
An honor to serve the country we love. An honor to bring the fight to our enemies abroad, so they never bring the fight to our fellow Americans here at home.
As veterans, we know what we signed up for. It was not a “service” in the traditional sense of the word… but rather an honor.

When you say “Never Forget” to a veteran, you are implying that, as an American, you are in it with them. Connected together as grateful Americans who will never forget the sacrifices made by veterans past and present, and their families, especially.

As a veteran, I always appreciate it when people say  “thank you” to veterans on this day.

But I also encourage them to say “Never Forget.”

to American Merchant Mariners who supplied our armed forces during World War II. I had the opportunity to meet with three World War II Merchant Mariners in my office.

With the greatest gratitude and respect, I would like to thank all veterans and those actively serving for their honor, courage, sacrifice, and dedication to our country. 
 
We may not know them all, but we owe them all. 🇺🇸
#VeteransDay

With the help of state and local leaders, we crafted a plan to meet both goals: increase the care provided at @EasternOKVA in Muskogee by adding a first of its kind, regional behavioral health center, but also to open a brand new, state of the art inpatient facility in Tulsa.

In Eastern Oklahoma, it became clear that we needed additional, updated infrastructure for our vets. Nationally, the need for a state of the art, modern behavioral health center was clear. I then began work with the @SecWilkie, to support our vets by utilizing the CHIP-IN Act.

I believe it's vital to give local communities the power to make their own decisions—they know what's best for their citizens. The Communities Helping Invest through Property & Improvements Needed for Veterans Act, or CHIP-IN Act, provides communities the ability to do just that.

It became clear that we needed to provide authority for VA directors to fire poorly performing employees, extend the Veterans Choice program and allow independent, third-party oversight at VA facilities. With @POTUS' signature in 2017, we enacted each of those reforms into law.

I was shocked when I read a USA Today article published in 2015 about the Oklahoma VA facilities—the conditions and situation were truly horrendous. After this was brought to my attention, I fought to ensure that our VA facilities were brought up to the highest standards of care.

As we honor those who have served this Veterans Day, it’s important to remember how much our nation’s vets have sacrificed. They deserve the highest level of care, & thanks to @POTUS, we have come a long way on that promise, especially in Oklahoma.
